ALLEGATION:
It is alleged that Youth A was able to access medication and ingest the bottle
of prescription medication. Staff do not have an explanation for how Youth A
was able to access the medication.
INVESTIGATION:
I received video footage of Youth A’s medication. The medication was in a pink
storage container lock box. There was no other youth’s medication in the box.
I interviewed Youth A, age 17, in her current placement location. Youth A alleged
she swallowed a half bottle of Lithium pills that was prescribed to her. She said no
one witnessed her taking the pills. She said her pills were on the kitchen table and
they had just been refilled. She said she took the pills because she was upset and
wanted to take her life. Youth A did not disclose why she was upset or why she
wanted to take her life in the beginning of this conversation. She said one of her
peers told Staff 1 that she had ingested the pills and Staff 1 made her throw up. She
did not identify the peer who told staff that she had taken the pills. She said she was
angry with the staff and the program because she felt she was lied to about the
program. She said she could not excel in the program and that she wanted to leave
and this was her way out. Youth A said she only took her pills that was sitting out on
the kitchen table. She vacillated between the number of pills she swallowed. She
said she took a half of bottle and there were 60 pills in the bottle. She then stated
she was unsure of how many pills she took on that day.
Youth A said she was transported to emergency at St. John’s hospital, and that her
agency caseworker went to the hospital with her. Youth A said she was at the
hospital for about a minute. She said the hospital staff monitored her Lithium levels
and she was released and went back to the Independent Living program.
I reviewed documentation from St. John’s Hospital dated 01/21/2022. The
instructions were to follow up within 3-7 days and continue to take medication as
prescribed. There were no procedures performed or documented for Youth A.
I interviewed Youth B, age 17, regarding the allegation. She said she did not
observe Youth A take any pills. She said she was in the area with Youth A the entire
time and that the girls had been smoking “Weed” including herself. She said the next
thing she knew; Youth A was told by Staff 1 to throw up and the supervisor call for
emergency and Youth A was transported to the hospital. Youth B said she was the
only other youth in the program who is prescribed medication. She said her
3

medication as well as Youth A’s medication is in a lock box and kept in their
bedrooms. She said they do not have access to each other’s medication.
I interviewed the agency caseworker. She reported Youth A told her she had
swallowed half of her medication and she told Youth A to throw up. She said she did
not know how many pills Youth A had swallowed because she did not know how
many pills Youth A had in her possession. She said she contacted the agency
supervisor and was informed to take Youth A to emergency. She said Youth A was
very rational while being transported to the hospital. Staff 1 said the doctor
examined Youth A and reported her vital signs were normal and her Lithium levels
were low and in average range. She said there were no other procedures
completed on Youth A and Youth A was discharged from the hospital.
I interviewed Youth A’s DHHS Worker. She reported that Youth A case is very
challenging and takes a lot of work. She described Youth A as being very intelligent
and knows the child welfare system very well. She said Youth A is influenced by her
mother. She said Youth A has AWOLed several times since being place in the IL
program and she does not follow directions. The worker said Youth A is very
manipulative and knows how to get her way. She said Youth A has been involved in
many fights and most of the fights, she instigates. She said Youth A is in the IL
Program because she is a hard to place youth given the fact that she is a dual ward
with assaultive behaviors.
I interviewed Youth A’s Probation Officer. She reported that Youth A does not have
any appropriate coping skills to assist her in de-escalating when she is out of control.
She said she was unaware that Youth A was prescribed Lithium pills. She said no
other placement was willing to take Youth A right now because she continues to
AWOL from her IL placement. She said Youth A was placed on 11/17/21 and have
had three AWOL’s. She said she wanted to file a petition on Youth A for violation of
probation for removal but was not able to do so. The Probation Officed said Youth A
was not ready for an IL placement because it afforded her to much independence
and Youth A cannot handle that. She said when Youth A was in her prior
placement, she completed her levels because she knows how to manipulate the
system and this was how she was able to go to an IL program. She stressed that
Youth A is a very intelligent young lady. She said Youth A had two drug screens
and they both tested positive for marijuana. The Probation Officer said she visited
with Youth A the day she said she swallowed her medication. She said when the
medication was dropped off she witness Youth A take the medication off the table
and place the medication in her lock box.
I reviewed the agency policy on medication. The policy states, youth are
responsible for prescribed prescriptions and non-prescription (over the counter)
medication. All medication prescribed and non-prescribed are stored in an assigned
container that will be given to the youth. The caseworker will assist the youth in
prefilling a prescribe medication, if applicable.
4

Youth will not exchange, administer or take another youth’s medication; this includes
prescribed and non-prescribed medication. Youth will not accept medication
(prescribed or non-prescribed) from Community Care Organization.
Staff may prompt the youth to take their medication but ultimately it is the youth
responsibility to take medication at the scheduled time. If the youth refuse to take
the prescribed medication, three times, a family team meeting (FTM) will be
scheduled. The youth may or may not be ask to attend the FTM.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
It is suggested that the agency put in place a system that is more accountable
in regard to medication being administered. It is suggested that an
assessment of the youth’s maturity level, cognitive functioning, and past
substance use be taken in consideration. It is suggested that a discussion
take place with the IL home and placing professionals to determine if the IL
home is the best placement to meet the needs of the IL youth regarding
prescribed medications prior to acceptance into the IL program.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12507 Medical/dental and mental health care.
(1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent
living receives any needed medical, dental, and mental
health care as required in R 400.12413. Medical, dental, and
mental health care provided shall be documented in the
youth's record.
ANALYSIS:
Youth A said she took a half of bottle of Lithium pills. She said
no one observed her take the pills but later said one of her
peers shared the information with the staff. The hospital
discharge papers performed no procedure on Youth A noting
her vital signs were good and her Lithium levels were low. She
was sent back to her IL placement. It is undetermined if Youth
A swallowed pills or not. There were no evidence to suggest
otherwise. The agency is not in violation with this rule.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
I recommend that Community Care Organization remain on their regular license.
